title: Comparative analysis of road safety parameters in the European motorways

author: Petros Evgenikos, National Technical University of Athens

segmentation: Ladies and gentlemen, good afternoon Anne.
My presentation.
I think it's not that complex as the one of the speaker before, so I think it will be much easier for you because it concerns a comparative analysis software.
The safety parameters in the European motorways.

As an introduction, we all know that motorways form an important part of the road infrastructure system in every country as they accommodate in big amounts of the traffic and also acknowledges us the safest roads by design.
They have specific features such as the high speeds and the separation of the flows of traffic by medium, size, shoulders, all the most important is the interchanges.
Additionally, they have more lanes enabling straightforward overtaking.
And then in general we can say that it's a best infrastructure that we can have in one country.
However, the statistics show that within the decade 1995 to 2004, more than a 25,000 people have lost their lives in accidents on motorways.
In 14 European Union countries within the same decade you can see that the fatalities and on motorways.
Decreased by 16%, whereas the over the overall Rd fatalities decreased by almost 30%.
Motorway networks are developing more and more across Europe so it's essential to investigate and monitor.
The accidental model waste enabling.
Thus, the implementation of the appropriate mitigation measures.
So it's very important to know what's happening if we want to find the proper solutions.
The objective of this study is the macroscopic analysis of Rd safety related parameters in European motorways and in order to.
In order to perform this analysis, we use the mainly accident data coming from the EU database named Care.
It's a database that includes a disaggregate around accident data and when possible we combine this data with the exposure data from international data files.
So what we wanted to do was to compare the countries and thus.
And subsequently allow for drawing an overall picture of the road safety level in the European motorways in comparison, of course with a non motorway Rd network.
And also we wanted to provide useful support to the decision makers working for the improvement of safety in the European Rd network.
